questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his foster mother because of poor performance at school for the past 8 months. His teachers reported that he does not listen to their instructions, often talks during class, and rarely completes his school assignments. He does not sit in his seat in the classroom and often cuts in line at the cafeteria. His foster mother reports that he runs around a lot inside the house and refuses to help his sister with chores and errands. He frequently interrupts his foster mother's conversations with others and talks excessively. She has found him trying to climb on the roof on multiple occasions. He was placed in foster care because of neglect by his biological parents 3 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mental status examination shows a neutral affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antisocial personality disorder may also present with impulsivity and disruptive behavior, as seen in this patient. Although a history of these behavioral changes with onset before age 15 is required, the patient has to be at least 18 years of age to make the diagnosis. Moreover, this patient lacks further findings of antisocial personality disorder such as a history of criminal behavior, deceit, and aggression.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) may also present with deficits in social interaction and communication at home and in school. However, in ASD this is rather due to deficits in social‐emotional reciprocity and developing and maintaining relationships and not due to impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, as seen in this patient. Moreover, the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, such as impaired language competence and nonverbal communication, cognitive deficits (or exceptional skills in a certain field), aberrant sensory perception, insistence on sameness, and restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities, makes the diagnosis unlikely. In addition, symptoms of ASD usually appear within the first 2–3 years of life.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with steady inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity for more than 6 months that severely impairs his school performance and family life. Such behavior is not age-appropriate and requires full evaluation by a doctor.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with specific learning disorders (dyslexia, dyscalculia or impairment in written expression) may also perform poorly at school, fail to follow instructions, and have difficulties completing tasks. However, this is rather due to impaired academic skills such as reading and/or difficulties understanding the meaning of what is read than due to inattention.

Specific learning disorders are a common comorbidity in this patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Conduct disorder (CD) may also present with disruptive behavior at home and school. However, patients with CD typically violate the rights of others (e.g., cruelty towards animals, stealing, and destruction of property), while this patient has no issues with others as such. Moreover, the diagnosis of CD requires that disruptive behavior persist ≥ 12 months.

F) INCORRECT:

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) may also present with problems at home and school and difficulties of following rules for ≥ 6 months. However, important other findings of ODD, such as frequent outbursts, excessive arguing, revenge-seeking behavior, and aggression towards figures of authority (e.g., teachers, parents), are missing in this patient. Methylphenidate does not improve symptoms of ODD.

ODD is one of the most common comorbidities in individuals with this patient's condition.

G) CORRECT:

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) should be suspected in children and adolescents that present with poor performance at school and difficulties concentrating and paying attention, as seen here. Several inattentive or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms must be present before the age of 12 years, in at least two different settings (e.g., school and at home), and for more than 6 months to an extent that is disruptive and inappropriate for the child's level of development. Common comorbidities include conduct disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, depression, anxiety disorder, substance abuse, and/or learning disorders. Management of ADHD is multimodal and typically consists of stimulants (e.g., methylphenidate) in combination with behavioral and school-based interventions.

Assessment of hearing is important in children with suspected ADHD, since children frustrated due to hearing impairment may act out similarly to patients with ADHD.

H) INCORRECT:

A child who is frustrated because he has impaired vision, hearing, and/or speaking may act out in the way seen in this child, which makes this an important differential diagnosis. However, this patient's neurological exam was normal.
questions.hint: Methylphenidate is one of the pharmacological agents approved to treat this condition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he does not “listen to her” anymore. She reports that since he started preschool 10 months ago, he has not been able to concentrate on any tasks lasting longer than a few minutes. His preschool teachers report he is more active compared to other preschoolers, frequently interrupts or bothers other children, and is very forgetful. He was born at term via vaginal delivery and has been healthy except for 3 episodes of acute otitis media at the age of 2 years. He has met all developmental milestones. His mother has major depressive disorder and his father has Graves disease. He appears healthy and well nourished. On examination, the patient turns his head briefly toward the examiner and sometimes makes eye contact when spoken to but does not respond to direct questions and continues to play with and touch objects in the physician's office. He interrupts his mother and the physician frequently during the examination to express his wish to go outside and eat a snack. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Behavioral interventions, including behavioral therapy and socio-educational measures (e.g., creation of a low-stimulus environment, providing support for learning disabilities), are considered the first-line treatment for ADHD in preschool-aged children (4–5 years of age). Behavioral therapy is most successful when guided by parents or guardians; for this reason, behavioral parent training is recommended for all parents of children with ADHD. Pharmacotherapy (preferably with stimulants such as methylphenidate) is only recommended in patients who are ≥ 6 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine therapy is indicated in the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD) and disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD). MDD can present with irritability, psychomotor agitation, and inability to concentrate, as seen in this patient. However, to diagnose MDD, ≥ 5 out of 9 typical symptoms, including anhedonia or depressed/irritable mood, have to be present over a 2-week period, which is not the case in this patient. As for DMDD, extreme irritability, anger, and severe recurrent angry outbursts (verbal or behavioral) in more than one setting are the findings required for diagnosis. Although this patient has been aggressive towards his teachers and classmates, he does not meet the criteria for this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

The use of hearing aids is indicated in children with conductive hearing loss. This boy's history of multiple episodes of acute otitis media should raise concern for hearing loss. However, the patient makes eye contact when spoken to. He also uses clear language and has reached all developmental milestones, which would be unlikely if hearing loss had been present from the age of 2. Hearing aids are not the best initial treatment for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Atomoxetine is considered the second-line treatment for ADHD in children ≥ 6 years of age, adolescents, and adults. However, it is preferred over stimulants (because of their addictive potential) in patients with a personal or family history of substance abuse and in patients with parents or guardians who object to the use of stimulants. Since this patient does not meet these criteria, atomoxetine would not be indicated. Furthermore, atomoxetine is also rarely used in patients < 6 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Stimulants such as methylphenidate are the first-line therapy for school-aged children (≥ 6 years of age) and adolescents with ADHD. Stimulants have a rapid onset of action and are very effective at increasing cognitive performance (e.g., improved concentration, cognition, short-term memory, and fine motor skills) and reducing impulsiveness and aggression. However, in preschool-aged children like this patient, methylphenidate is only used if first-line treatment is not met with an adequate response.
questions.hint: This patient presents with impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention in two settings (at school and at home) for more than 6 months, which is consistent with the diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of teacher complaints regarding his poor performance at school for the past 8 months. He has difficulty sustaining attention when assigned school-related tasks, does not follow the teachers' instructions, and makes careless mistakes in his homework. He often blurts out answers in class and has difficulty adhering to the rules during soccer practice. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks with him and that he often forgets his books at school. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on the appropriate first-line therapy. This boy is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A prolonged QT interval can be caused by antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., amiodarone), antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol), antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline), phenothiazines, and first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine). While the medication used for this patient's condition may induce tachycardia, it is not associated with a prolonged QT interval.

B) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome is a condition caused by intake of serotonergic drugs (e.g., SSRIs). While it may present with some symptoms similar to the adverse effects caused by the medication given to this boy, serotonergic drugs are not indicated in the treatment of his condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Common medications that increase appetite or reduce metabolism and lead to weight gain include antipsychotics and antidepressants, which are not indicated in the treatment of the patient's condition. The medication he is receiving typically reduces appetite and can lead to weight loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Medications that may impair liver function and lead to an elevation of transaminases include acetaminophen, statins, and some anticonvulsants (e.g., valproate) and antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin). The medication this patient is receiving is not known to impair liver function.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased perspiration is an adverse effect of anticholinergics (antimuscarinic agents) which are used to suppress functions of the parasympathetic nervous system (e.g., in the treatment of asthma, urinary incontinence). The first-line treatment given for this boy's condition typically has a sympathomimetic effect and increases perspiration.

F) CORRECT:

This boy is most likely being treated with methylphenidate, which is first-line pharmacotherapy for ADHD. Methylphenidate has sympathomimetic activity and improves concentration, cognition, and short-term memory. Common adverse sympathomimetic effects include elevated arterial blood pressure, tachycardia, sweating, insomnia, decreased seizure threshold, and a reduced appetite/stunted growth.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity present in more than one setting (at home, in school, soccer practice), onset of symptoms before 12 years of age, and duration of symptoms for ≥ 6 months fulfill the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is one of the most commonly used first-line medications.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor performance in school for the last year. He has difficulty sitting still at his desk, does not follow the teacher's instructions, and frequently blurts out answers in class. He often gets sent outside the classroom for failing to work quietly. At hockey practice, he does not wait his turn and has difficulty listening to his coach's instructions. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks with him and that he often forgets his books at home. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Atomoxetine is a nonstimulant drug for treating ADHD and is prescribed for patients who cannot tolerate stimulants, such as methylphenidate. Atomoxetine carries a black-box warning for increased suicidal ideation in children and adolescents, so treatment must be monitored closely. Other nonstimulant drugs approved for the treatment of ADHD include clonidine and guanfacine.

B) INCORRECT:

Suvorexant is used to treat insomnia. It does not have a role in treating ADHD.

C) INCORRECT:

Buspirone is an anxiolytic drug used to treat generalized anxiety disorder. Patients with ADHD are at an increased risk of developing anxiety disorders. However, this patient lacks signs of anxiety, and therefore, is unlikely to benefit from buspirone. This drug has no role in managing hyperactivity and inattention in ADHD.

D) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic drug used in the treatment of several pediatric neuropsychiatric conditions, including Tourette syndrome and obsessive-compulsive disorder, as well as aggression in children with autism disorder. This drug has no role in managing hyperactivity and inattention in ADHD.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is used to treat several neuropsychiatric illnesses, including major depressive disorder (MDD), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), and panic disorder. Although MDD and OCD are potential comorbid conditions of ADHD, this patient lacks findings consistent with these conditions. Fluoxetine is not indicated to manage hyperactivity and inattention in ADHD.

F) INCORRECT:

Varenicline is used to aid smoking cessation. It has no role in treating ADHD.
questions.hint: These findings meet diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Both stimulants and nonstimulants are approved to treat this condition.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He was recently fired from his job as a cashier because of mistakes and absenteeism. He says that he finds it difficult to maintain focus on any task and often feels restless. He admits that he often forgets to pay his bills and often misplaces his cell phone and keys. He has had poor academic performance and dropped out of high school at 15 years of age. He drinks three to four beers on weekends and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. He is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. His mother has a history of opioid use disorder. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a normal mood and a reactive affect. A diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder with a predominantly inattentive presentation is made. The physician explains the implications of the diagnosis, various treatment options, and the adverse effects of each treatment. The patient is concerned about his risk for a substance use disorder given his family history. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alpha-2 receptor agonists, such as guanfacine, have not been shown to be effective in the treatment of adults with ADHD. In children and adolescents, these drugs are used for patients who fail to respond to first-line pharmacotherapy (e.g., methylphenidate) or experience adverse effects in response to treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), such as nortriptyline, can be used in combination with other medications to treat ADHD, especially in patients who have concomitant anxiety disorders or major depressive disorder. However, TCAs tend to be less effective and more poorly tolerated than other pharmacotherapeutic options. Adverse effects include cardiotoxicity, seizures, anticholinergic effects, and antihistaminic effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine, can be used in combination with other medications to treat ADHD, especially in patients who have concomitant anxiety disorders. However, SNRIs are not effective as monotherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant drug that is commonly used to treat ADHD, given its high efficacy and quick onset of initial effect (≤ 1 hour). However, it has a high potential for addiction. For patients who have a personal history of substance use disorder or are concerned about the addictive effects of stimulants, a different medication is preferred.

E) CORRECT:

Nonstimulant drugs, such as atomoxetine, are the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for patients with ADHD who have a personal history of substance use disorder or are concerned about the addictive effects of stimulant drugs. Although nonstimulant drugs are typically less effective and have a delayed onset of therapeutic action (1–2 weeks) compared to stimulant drugs (e.g., methylphenidate, which acts in ≤ 1 hour), they are not associated with drug dependence or misuse. Bupropion is also an acceptable nonstimulant drug to treat ADHD, especially for patients with concomitant major depressive disorder.

F) INCORRECT:

Methylphenidate is a stimulant drug that is commonly used to treat ADHD given its high efficacy and quick onset of initial effect (≤ 1 hour). However, it has a high potential for addiction. For patients who have a personal history of substance use disorder or are concerned about the addictive effects of stimulants, a different medication is preferred.
questions.hint: The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can take 1–2 weeks of administration before having a therapeutic effect.

questions.text:
The parents of a 7-year-old boy report that he is having behavioral problems in school. His academic skills are strong, but he is impulsive. He has difficulty staying on task and remaining quiet while the teacher is talking. When students line up, he pushes to the front of the line. At home, his parents have trouble getting him to comply with their requests; he needs frequent reminders to sit and do his homework.
His vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Eliminate refined sugar from the child’s diet
Ask the parents and the child’s teacher to complete a behavioral questionnaire
Recommend initiation of a token economy behavior plan
Refer the child for psychoeducational testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elimination diets are unlikely to be harmful, but they are not recommended, as there is insufficient data to demonstrate any clinically significant effect on behavior.

B) CORRECT:

In a child suspected of having attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), the most appropriate next step is to obtain standardized behavioral information from both his parents and his teacher so that his symptoms can be documented. Behavior-rating questionnaires, such as the Conners Rating Scale and the Vanderbilt Assessment Scales, can help delineate a child’s attention and activity levels and can also suggest the need for further evaluation of oppositional or other disruptive behaviors. When time permits, interview and observation in the office is also an appropriate method to diagnose ADHD.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial evaluation in a child with features of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder is a behavior-rating scale questionnaire.

C) INCORRECT:

A token economy behavior plan, which is a system of behavior modification based on the systematic reinforcement of target behavior, is appropriate for some behavioral issues, such as encouraging children to read more or perform chores at home. However, a comprehensive evaluation of the child is needed before a behavioral plan is created.

D) INCORRECT:

A diagnosis of ADHD would be necessary before initiating therapy with a stimulant medication, such as methylphenidate, even on a trial basis.

E) INCORRECT:

Psychoeducational testing is indicated for a child with academic issues to assess whether a learning disability is affecting the child's school performance.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy with mild intellectual impairment has trouble paying attention in the classroom and difficulty staying in his seat, which is affecting his school performance. He is pleasant and nonaggressive, but his parents report that he is has difficulty focusing on tasks even at home. Review of teacher and parent rating forms document high scores for inattention and hyperactivity and low scores for aggression and problematic peer relations.
In addition to behavioral therapy, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend a diet low in refined sugars

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The use of atypical antipsychotic, such as risperidone, would not be indicated unless a child exhibited aggressive or self-injurious behavior, irritability, or explosive outbursts that were not responsive to stimulant therapy. Notably, such behaviors would rule out simple ADHD alone and would suggest the possibility of an alternative diagnosis or comorbid condition, such as oppositional defiant disorder, intermittent explosive disorder, or conduct disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance alone would not be adequate for a child with features of ADHD that are affecting his school performance.

C) INCORRECT:

Although some studies have demonstrated reduced fatty acid levels in children with ADHD, there is no evidence to support supplementation with essential fatty acids to improve symptoms in children with ADHD.

D) INCORRECT:

Dietary interventions are not considered first-line therapy for ADHD and are not recommended in current treatment guidelines.

E) CORRECT:

This child's evaluation points to attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The recommended treatment for children with ADHD varies according to age.

• For children younger than 6 years of age, behavioral therapy alone is first-line treatment, with medications reserved for those who have severe symptoms or those who have moderate symptoms that do not improve with behavioral therapy.
• For school-age children (age ≥6) and adolescents, initial treatment consists of a stimulant medication, behavioral therapy, or (preferably) both.

Given that this child is 7 years old with features of ADHD that are affecting his school performance, intervention is warranted. Therapy with a stimulant, such as methylphenidate, is an appropriate option, especially if it is coupled with behavioral therapy. Among children with ADHD, those who take medication to treat the condition tend to do better in math and reading than those who do not take medication. Stimulants can be effective even in individuals who have intellectual disabilities.

For patients who are unable to tolerate stimulants, the selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor atomoxetine and the alpha-2-adrenergic agonists guanfacine and clonidine may be considered. These agents have shown some benefit in symptom management but are less effective than stimulants and are thus considered second-line.

Key learning point: The best initial medication class for a 7-year-old child with features of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder is a stimulant medication.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents with his mother for a routine checkup. His medical history is significant only for attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, which was diagnosed at age 8. He has been taking methylphenidate since his diagnosis, with appropriate dose adjustments for growth, and his mother reports good adherence to the medication. His symptoms have generally been well controlled, with improvements noted in his ability to pay attention, to follow instructions, to complete schoolwork on time, and to interact with his peers.
Today, his mother reports that his academic performance has recently started to decline, with an increasing number of incomplete assignments and lower grades. At home, he has been having trouble sleeping and does not want to play with friends as much as he used to.
The boy appears well, and his vital signs are within normal limits. He weighs 37 kg (50th percentile for age) and is 150 cm tall (52nd percentile for age), for a BMI of 16.7 (40th percentile for age). His pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. His ear, nose, and throat examination reveals moist, pink mucous membranes, with a normal oropharynx and normal tympanic membranes. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and his cardiac, neurologic, and musculoskeletal examinations are normal.
What is the most likely reason for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient with attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) has been successfully treated with ADHD medication for 3 years and now has reduced school performance, trouble sleeping, and a lack of interest in friends. Although inadequate dosing of medication is often a consideration when a patient relapses while on therapy, it is unlikely to be the culprit in this case. Once a therapeutic dose of stimulant medication is reached, dose adjustments are needed only to account for a patient's growth, and this patient has had such adjustments appropriately over time. The more likely explanation for the patient's new symptoms is a comorbid condition.

ADHD is frequently associated with depressive disorders, conduct disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, learning disabilities, and intellectual disability. Patients who meet the diagnostic criteria for ADHD but do not improve with appropriate ADHD treatment should be evaluated for comorbid conditions that may have initially been untreated or unrecognized. Similarly, patients who develop new symptoms while receiving adequate treatment (as in this case) should be evaluated for comorbid conditions that may have recently arisen. In this case, a depressive disorder is a likely cause of this patient’s declining school performance, poor sleep, and decreased interest in friends. He should be evaluated for a possible depressive disorder, and if that diagnosis is confirmed, he should be started in psychotherapy, on a medication trial, or both.

Key learning point: Depressive disorders are a common comorbidity of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) that can cause decreased attention and irritability despite adequate treatment for the ADHD.

B) INCORRECT:

Lead toxicity is in the differential diagnosis for ADHD but is not an expected comorbid condition. This patient does not have a history of physical clues to suggest this diagnosis, and his symptoms were well treated for several years with ADHD medication.

C) INCORRECT:

Although inadequate dosing of medication is often a consideration when a patient relapses while on therapy, it is unlikely to be the culprit in this case. Once a therapeutic dose of stimulant medication is reached, dose adjustments are needed only to account for a patient's growth, and this patient has had such adjustments appropriately over time. The more likely explanation for the patient's new symptoms is a comorbid condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Obstructive sleep apnea is in the differential diagnosis for ADHD but is not an expected comorbid condition. This patient does not have a history of physical clues to suggest this diagnosis, and his symptoms were well treated for several years with ADHD medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Although learning disabilities are a common comorbidity with ADHD, they are not likely in this patient, given that his school performance initially improved with a stimulant.

D) INCORRECT:

A diagnosis of ADHD would be necessary before initiating therapy with a stimulant medication, such as methylphenidate, even on a trial basis.

E) INCORRECT:

Psychoeducational testing is indicated for a child with academic issues to assess whether a learning disability is affecting the child's school performance.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has trouble paying attention in the classroom and difficulty staying in his seat, which is affecting his school performance. He is pleasant and nonaggressive, but his parents report that he has difficulty focusing on tasks even at home. Review of teacher and parent rating forms document high scores for inattention and hyperactivity and low scores for aggression and problematic peer relations. In addition to behavioral therapy, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend a diet low in refined sugars

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The use of atypical antipsychotic, such as risperidone, would not be indicated unless a child exhibited aggressive or self-injurious behavior, irritability, or explosive outbursts that were not responsive to stimulant therapy. Notably, such behaviors would rule out simple ADHD alone and would suggest the possibility of an alternative diagnosis or comorbid condition, such as oppositional defiant disorder, intermittent explosive disorder, or conduct disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance alone would not be adequate for a child with features of ADHD that are affecting his school performance.

C) INCORRECT:

Although some studies have demonstrated reduced fatty acid levels in children with ADHD, there is no evidence to support supplementation with essential fatty acids to improve symptoms in children with ADHD.

D) INCORRECT:

Dietary interventions are not considered first-line therapy for ADHD and are not recommended in current treatment guidelines.

• For children younger than 6 years of age, behavioral therapy alone is first-line treatment, with medications reserved for those who have severe symptoms or those who have moderate symptoms that do not improve with behavioral therapy.
• For school-age children (age ≥6) and adolescents, initial treatment consists of a stimulant medication, behavioral therapy, or (preferably) both.

Given that this child is 7 years old with features of ADHD that are affecting his school performance, intervention is warranted. Therapy with a stimulant, such as methylphenidate, is an appropriate option, especially if it is coupled with behavioral therapy. Among children with ADHD, those who take medication to treat the condition tend to do better in math and reading than those who do not take medication.

For patients who are unable to tolerate stimulants, the selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor atomoxetine and the alpha-2-adrenergic agonists guanfacine and clonidine may be considered. questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for evaluation due to ongoing academic difficulties and behavior problems at school. He is easily distracted, often leaves his seat, and has trouble completing homework. His teacher notes frequent interruptions during class and restlessness throughout the day. Developmental history is within normal limits, and there are no reported mood disturbances or psychotic symptoms. Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic intervention for this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alpha-2 agonists, such as guanfacine and clonidine, modulate noradrenergic tone and can reduce hyperactivity and impulsivity. They are typically used as adjuncts to stimulants or when stimulants are contraindicated. In uncomplicated ADHD, stimulants are the preferred initial pharmacologic intervention.

B) CORRECT:

In pediatric patients with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), stimulant medications are the first-line treatment. Extended-release methylphenidate provides consistent medication levels throughout the day, effectively managing symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. It works by inhibiting dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake, enhancing neurotransmission in brain regions responsible for executive function and attention. The extended-release formulation offers sustained symptom control, improved adherence with once-daily dosing, and a reduced risk of rebound effects or misuse compared to immediate-release formulations.

Key learning point: Stimulant medications like dextroamphetamine are the first-line treatment for managing symptoms of ADHD in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Aripiprazole, an atypical antipsychotic, is used for schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and irritability in autism spectrum disorder. It does not address the core deficits of ADHD, which involve dopamine and norepinephrine dysregulation. Stimulants are preferred for ADHD due to their direct action on these neurotransmitter systems.

D) INCORRECT:

Sertraline, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is primarily used for mood and anxiety disorders. The child presents with symptoms suggestive of ADHD, not mood or anxiety disorders. Sertraline's mechanism, focusing on serotonin modulation, does not address the dopamine and norepinephrine imbalances associated with ADHD.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because his teachers have reported poor school performance over the past 8 months. He has difficulty sustaining attention on school tasks, does not follow instructions, and makes careless mistakes on his homework. In class, he often blurts out answers and has trouble following rules during soccer practice. His mother notes that he is easily distracted when she talks to him and frequently forgets his books at school. Physical examination is normal. You start him on the appropriate first-line therapy. This boy is at increased risk for which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome is a condition caused by intake of serotonergic drugs (e.g., SSRIs). While it may present with some symptoms similar to the adverse effects caused by the medication given to this boy, serotonergic drugs are not indicated in the treatment of his condition.

B) CORRECT:

This boy is most likely being treated with methylphenidate, which is first-line pharmacotherapy for ADHD. Methylphenidate has sympathomimetic activity and improves concentration, cognition, and short-term memory. Common adverse sympathomimetic effects include elevated arterial blood pressure, tachycardia, sweating, insomnia, decreased seizure threshold, and a reduced appetite/stunted growth.

Key learning point: Methylphenidate, the first-line treatment for ADHD, commonly causes sympathomimetic side effects such as elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, insomnia, and decreased appetite.

C) INCORRECT:

Medications that may impair liver function and lead to an elevation of transaminases include acetaminophen, statins, and some anticonvulsants (e.g., valproate) and antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin). The medication this patient is receiving is not known to impair liver function.

D) INCORRECT:

Common medications that increase appetite or reduce metabolism and lead to weight gain include antipsychotics and antidepressants, which are not indicated in the treatment of the patient's condition. The medication he is receiving typically reduces appetite and can lead to weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

A prolonged QT interval can be caused by antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., amiodarone), antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol), antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline), phenothiazines, and first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine). While the medication used for this patient's condition may induce tachycardia, it is not associated with a prolonged QT interval.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity present in more than one setting (at home, in school, soccer practice), onset of symptoms before 12 years of age, and duration of symptoms for ≥ 6 months fulfill the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is one of the most commonly used first-line medications.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his foster mother because of poor school performance over the past 8 months. His teachers report that he does not listen to instructions, often talks during class, rarely completes assignments, does not remain seated, and frequently cuts in line at the cafeteria. At home, his foster mother notes that he is very active indoors, frequently interrupts conversations, and has attempted to climb onto the roof multiple times. On mental status examination, his affect is neutral. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) may also present with problems at home and school and difficulties of following rules for ≥ 6 months. However, important other findings of ODD, such as frequent outbursts, excessive arguing, revenge-seeking behavior, and aggression towards figures of authority (e.g., teachers, parents), are missing in this patient. Methylphenidate does not improve symptoms of ODD.

ODD is one of the most common comorbidities in individuals with this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) may also present with deficits in social interaction and communication at home and in school. However, in ASD this is rather due to deficits in social‐emotional reciprocity and developing and maintaining relationships and not due to impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, as seen in this patient. Moreover, the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, such as impaired language competence and nonverbal communication, cognitive deficits (or exceptional skills in a certain field), aberrant sensory perception, insistence on sameness, and restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities, makes the diagnosis unlikely. In addition, symptoms of ASD usually appear within the first 2–3 years of life.

C) CORRECT:

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) should be suspected in children and adolescents that present with poor performance at school and difficulties concentrating and paying attention, as seen here. Several inattentive or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms must be present before the age of 12 years, in at least two different settings (e.g., school and at home), and for more than 6 months to an extent that is disruptive and inappropriate for the child's level of development. Common comorbidities include conduct disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, depression, anxiety disorder, substance abuse, and/or learning disorders. Management of ADHD is multimodal and typically consists of stimulants (e.g., methylphenidate) in combination with behavioral and school-based interventions.

Assessment of hearing is important in children with suspected ADHD, since children frustrated due to hearing impairment may act out similarly to patients with ADHD.

Key learning point: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is characterized by persistent inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity in multiple settings, leading to significant impairment in academic and social functioning.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with steady inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity for more than 6 months that severely impairs his school performance and family life. Such behavior is not age-appropriate and requires full evaluation by a doctor.

E) INCORRECT:

Conduct disorder (CD) may also present with disruptive behavior at home and school. However, patients with CD typically violate the rights of others (e.g., cruelty towards animals, stealing, and destruction of property), while this patient has no issues with others as such. Moreover, the diagnosis of CD requires that disruptive behavior persist ≥ 12 months.
questions.hint: Methylphenidate is one of the pharmacological agents approved to treat this condition.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder comes to your clinic to discuss treatment options. He was recently fired from his job as a cashier due to mistakes and absenteeism. He reports difficulty maintaining focus on tasks and often feels restless. His mother has a history of opioid use disorder. Vital signs are normal. You review various treatment options and discuss the potential adverse effects of each. He expresses concern about his risk for developing a substance use disorder given his family history. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nonstimulant drugs, such as atomoxetine, are the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for patients with ADHD who have a personal history of substance use disorder or are concerned about the addictive effects of stimulant drugs. Although nonstimulant drugs are typically less effective and have a delayed onset of therapeutic action (1–2 weeks) compared to stimulant drugs (e.g., methylphenidate, which acts in ≤ 1 hour), they are not associated with drug dependence or misuse. Bupropion is also an acceptable nonstimulant drug to treat ADHD, especially for patients with concomitant major depressive disorder.

Key learning point: Atomoxetine, a nonstimulant, is preferred for treating ADHD in patients at risk for substance use disorder due to its low potential for abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine, can be used in combination with other medications to treat ADHD, especially in patients who have concomitant anxiety disorders. However, SNRIs are not effective as monotherapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-2 receptor agonists, such as guanfacine, have not been shown to be effective in the treatment of adults with ADHD. In children and adolescents, these drugs are used for patients who fail to respond to first-line pharmacotherapy (e.g., methylphenidate) or experience adverse effects in response to treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Methylphenidate is a stimulant drug that is commonly used to treat ADHD given its high efficacy and quick onset of initial effect (≤ 1 hour). However, it has a high potential for addiction. For patients who have a personal history of substance use disorder or are concerned about the addictive effects of stimulants, a different medication is preferred.

E) INCORRECT:

Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant drug that is commonly used to treat ADHD, given its high efficacy and quick onset of initial effect (≤ 1 hour). However, it has a high potential for addiction. For patients who have a personal history of substance use disorder or are concerned about the addictive effects of stimulants, a different medication is preferred.
questions.hint: The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can take 1–2 weeks of administration before having a therapeutic effect.

questions.text: The parents of a 7-year-old boy bring him to your clinic because of concerns about behavioral problems at school. His academic performance is strong, but he is described as impulsive, has difficulty staying on task, and often interrupts the teacher. He pushes to the front of the line when students are lining up. At home, his parents report difficulty getting him to follow instructions and that he requires frequent reminders to sit and complete his homework. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Recommend initiation of a token economy behavior plan.
Refer the child for psychoeducational testing.
Eliminate refined sugar from the child’s diet.
Ask the parents and the child’s teacher to complete a behavioral questionnaire.

questions.solution:

However, a comprehensive evaluation of the child is needed before a behavioral plan is created.

B) INCORRECT:

Psychoeducational testing is indicated for a child with academic issues to assess whether a learning disability is affecting the child's school performance.

C) INCORRECT:

A diagnosis of ADHD would be necessary before initiating therapy with a stimulant medication, such as methylphenidate, even on a trial basis.

D) INCORRECT:

Elimination diets are unlikely to be harmful, but they are not recommended, as there is insufficient data to demonstrate any clinically significant effect on behavior.

E) CORRECT:

In a child suspected of having attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), the most appropriate next step is to obtain standardized behavioral information from both his parents and his teacher so that his symptoms can be documented. Behavior-rating questionnaires, such as the Conners Rating Scale and the Vanderbilt Assessment Scales, can help delineate a child’s attention and activity levels and can also suggest the need for further evaluation of oppositional or other disruptive behaviors. When time permits, interview and observation in the office is also an appropriate method to diagnose ADHD.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial evaluation in a child with features of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder is a behavior-rating scale questionnaire.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with persistent inattention, impulsivity, and disruptive outbursts at home and school. His parents are frustrated by repeated punishments. What intervention is most likely to improve his behavior?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Family therapy addresses relational dysfunction and negative communication patterns within the family. However, the child's symptoms of inattention, impulsivity, and disruptive outbursts are characteristic of ADHD, which responds better to interventions directly targeting these deficits, such as structured behavior programs.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing punishments is ineffective for children with ADHD, who struggle with impulse control and self-regulation. Punitive measures can increase frustration and impair the parent-child relationship. Evidence-based management emphasizes structured behavioral interventions and positive reinforcement.

C) INCORRECT:

Cognitive therapy involves modifying negative thought patterns and is more effective in older adolescents and adults. An 8-year-old with ADHD lacks the abstract reasoning and self-reflective skills needed for cognitive therapy, making behavioral interventions more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

A structured parent-training behavior program provides parents with strategies to manage attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) symptoms through consistent routines, positive reinforcement, and behavior modification techniques. These programs use operant conditioning principles, enabling parents to apply immediate, targeted responses to behaviors, reinforcing desirable actions and minimizing disruptive outbursts. By enhancing parental skills and increasing consistency between home and school settings, these programs can significantly improve the child's attention, impulsivity, and overall behavior.

Key learning point: Parent training programs and behavior management techniques are effective strategies for managing ADHD by reinforcing positive behaviors and managing negative ones.
